SENT.plain: Subclavian artery aneurysm is relatively rare, but, we can scarcely find mention in the literature of a subclavian-vertebral junction aneurysm
We report a case of a 73-year-old man with a left subclavian-vertebral junction arterial aneurysm of 11 mm in diameter which caused a brain stem thromboembolism
He showed right hemiparesis and dysarthria on admission
On the 5th day after admission, his hemiparesis worsened and he could not even walk
In order to prevent further embolic attack on the vertebro-basilar system and rupture from the aneurysm, we embolized the aneurysm successfully with some GDC coils
During the operation, no further brain infarction occurred, and we maintained blood circulation in the left subclavian-vertebral artery
This aneurysm appeared on angiography to be atherosclerotic in its clinical characteristics, and we have scheduled follow-up angiography in two years time
As his hemiparesis had improved, he was discharged from the hospital on foot
